subject: Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... You lead to a very interesting point: how should personal idiosyncraticies be handled? And what about the accent of non-native English speakers? Do we
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:

You lead to a very interesting point: how should personal
idiosyncraticies be handled? And what about the accent of non-native
English speakers? Do we instruct people to speak the way they think
their accent *should* sound? Quite something to think about.

>
> Dear Gregory:
>
> I recently inquired of John C. Wells, a linguist who lectures at
> University College in London, about the substitution of "chr" for
"tr".
> According to him, this is not a known dialect from any geographical
> region, but is, apparently, a peculiarity of some people's speech,
and I
> suspect a very small percentage of English speakers do this.
>
> Paige
>
